page.title: 17Ecology
page.content: Totternhoe Knolls is an area of great interest for its flora and fauna and is widely visited for walks and picnics. Managed by the Beds and Huntingdon Naturalist Trust and also Beds County Council, many plants common to chalk districts, but often rare countrywide, may be discovered here. Of particular interest are a profusion of cowslips and wild orchids; in particular bee orchids and pyramid orchids. Although previously wellknown for its beech trees, the County has a difficult job keeping the scrub from swamping the area. Around the Castleyard many rabbits may be seen and occasionally roebuck deer. The area is rich in varieties of moths and butterflies. Cinnabar, burnet, magpie, heart and dart moths may be seen regularly although the peppered moth ({betularia}) is ...
